article:
Olympiacos F.C.
================

Olympiacos F.C., also known as Olympiacos Piraeus or simply Olympiacos, is a Greek professional football club based in Piraeus, Greece. The club was founded in 1925 and has since become one of the most successful and popular football clubs in Greece, with a record 47 Greek League titles and 28 Greek Cups.

History
-------

### Early years (1925–1931)

Olympiacos was founded in 1925 by a group of Greek football enthusiasts, led by Notis Kamperos. The club's early years were marked by struggles, both on and off the pitch. In 1926, Olympiacos joined the Piraeus Football Clubs Association and began competing in local tournaments. The club's first major success came in 1928, when they won the Piraeus Championship.

### Domination in Greece and World War II (1931–1946)

The 1930s were a successful period for Olympiacos, as they won their first Greek League title in 1931 and went on to dominate Greek football for the next decade. The club won five consecutive Greek League titles between 1931 and 1936, and also won the Greek Cup in 1931 and 1933. During World War II, Olympiacos continued to compete in local tournaments and won several regional titles.

### The Legend (1946–1959)

The post-war period saw the emergence of Olympiacos as a major force in Greek football. The club won several Greek League titles and Greek Cups, and also competed in European competitions for the first time. In 1951, Olympiacos became the first Greek club to compete in the European Cup.

### First international success and Márton Bukovi era (1960–1972)

The 1960s were a successful period for Olympiacos, as they won several Greek League titles and Greek Cups. The club also achieved their first international success, winning the Balkans Cup in 1963. In 1964, Márton Bukovi became the club's coach and led Olympiacos to several domestic and international titles.

### Goulandris era (1972–1975)

In 1972, Olympiacos was taken over by the Goulandris family, who invested heavily in the club. During this period, Olympiacos won several Greek League titles and Greek Cups, and also competed in European competitions.

### Domination in the early 1980s, four consecutive League titles (1975–1987)

The 1980s were a successful period for Olympiacos, as they won four consecutive Greek League titles between 1980 and 1983. The club also won several Greek Cups and competed in European competitions.

### The Stone Years, UEFA Cup quarter-finalists (1987–1996)

The late 1980s and early 1990s were a difficult period for Olympiacos, as the club faced financial difficulties and struggled on the pitch. However, in 1992, Olympiacos reached the quarter-finals of the UEFA Cup, where they were eliminated by Real Madrid.

### The Golden Era (1996–2010)

The 1996 appointment of coach Dušan Bajević marked the beginning of a new era for Olympiacos. The club won several Greek League titles and Greek Cups, and also competed in European competitions.

#### Seven consecutive League titles, near-miss to UEFA Champions League semi-finals (1996–2003)

Between 1996 and 2003, Olympiacos won seven consecutive Greek League titles and reached the quarter-finals of the UEFA Champions League, where they were eliminated by Juventus.

#### Five consecutive League titles, Two presences in UEFA Champions League knockout phase (2004–2010)

Between 2004 and 2010, Olympiacos won five consecutive Greek League titles and reached the knockout phase of the UEFA Champions League twice.

### New presidency, seven consecutive League titles and European ascent (2010–2017)

In 2010, Evangelos Marinakis became the club's president and invested heavily in the club. Between 2010 and 2017, Olympiacos won seven consecutive Greek League titles and reached the knockout phase of the UEFA Champions League twice.

### European successes, three consecutive Greek League titles (2017–2023)

Between 2017 and 2023, Olympiacos won three consecutive Greek League titles and reached the knockout phase of the UEFA Europa League twice.

### UEFA Europa Conference League Winners & UEFA Youth League Winners (2023–24)

In the 2023-24 season, Olympiacos won the UEFA Europa Conference League and the UEFA Youth League.

Crest and colours
-----------------

### Kit evolution

Olympiacos' kit has undergone several changes throughout the club's history. The club's traditional colours are red and white.

### Kit manufacturers and shirt sponsors

Olympiacos' kit is currently manufactured by Adidas, and the club's shirt sponsor is Stoiximan.

Stadium
--------

Olympiacos plays its home matches at the Georgios Karaiskakis Stadium, which has a capacity of 32,115.

Support
-------

### Friendships

Olympiacos has friendships with several Greek clubs, including AEK Athens and PAOK.

### The Gate 7 tragedy

In 1981, 21 Olympiacos fans were killed in a stampede at the Karaiskakis Stadium, in an incident known as the Gate 7 tragedy.

Rivalries
----------

Olympiacos has rivalries with several Greek clubs, including Panathinaikos and AEK Athens.

European and International performance
--------------------------------------

### UEFA competition record

Olympiacos has competed in several UEFA competitions, including the European Cup, UEFA Cup, and UEFA Champions League.

### Best campaigns

Olympiacos' best campaigns in European competitions include reaching the quarter-finals of the UEFA Cup in 1993 and the knockout phase of the UEFA Champions League in 2008 and 2014.

### UEFA ranking

Olympiacos is currently ranked 24th in the UEFA club coefficient rankings.

1987 in the United States

The year 1987 in the United States was marked by significant events that shaped the country's politics, economy, culture, and society. It was the seventh year of the presidency of Ronald Reagan, who continued to implement his conservative policies and reinforce the country's position as a global superpower.

# Incumbents

## Federal government

* President: Ronald Reagan (R-California)
* Vice President: George H.W. Bush (R-Texas)
* Speaker of the House of Representatives: Tip O'Neill (D-Massachusetts) (until January 3), Jim Wright (D-Texas) (from January 6)
* President pro tempore of the Senate: Strom Thurmond (R-South Carolina)
* Chief Justice: William Rehnquist

# Events

## January

* January 2: Chadian-Libyan conflict: The Chadian army, backed by French air support, launches a successful counterattack against Libyan forces in Chad.
* January 3: Aretha Franklin becomes the first woman to be inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame.
* January 25: Super Bowl XXI: The New York Giants defeat the Denver Broncos 39-20 at the Rose Bowl in Pasadena, California.

## February

* February 11: The United States Supreme Court upholds the right of the government to give preference to companies owned by minorities and women in the case of City of Richmond v. J.A. Croson Co.
* February 23: The Supernova 1987A is observed, becoming the closest observed supernova to Earth since 1604.

## March

* March 6: The United States and the Soviet Union agree to a joint mission to Mars, with the goal of launching the spacecraft in 1992.
* March 11: U2 releases their album "The Joshua Tree", which becomes a huge commercial success and is widely regarded as one of the greatest albums of all time.
* March 30: Vincent van Gogh's painting "Sunflowers" is sold at auction for $39.7 million, a record price for a painting at the time.

## April

* April 13: Portugal and China sign the Sino-Portuguese Joint Declaration, which will lead to the transfer of sovereignty over Macau from Portugal to China in 1999.
* April 15: The first reported case of a computer virus, the "Creeper" virus, is discovered on the ARPANET network.
* April 21: The Tamil Tigers launch a rebellion against the government of Sri Lanka, which will lead to a long and bloody civil war.

## May

* May 11: The first heart-lung transplant is performed by a team of surgeons at Stanford University.
* May 15: The Soviet Union launches the Mir space station, which will remain in orbit until 2001.
* May 21: The United States and the Soviet Union sign the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty, which will lead to the destruction of over 2,000 nuclear missiles.

## June

* June 8: New Zealand's Labour government introduces the New Zealand Nuclear Free Zone, Disarmament, and Arms Control Act, which bans nuclear-powered ships and nuclear weapons from the country's territory.
* June 12: During a speech in Berlin, President Ronald Reagan challenges Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev to "tear down this wall", referring to the Berlin Wall.
* June 26: The United States Supreme Court rules in the case of Edwards v. Aguillard that a Louisiana law requiring the teaching of creationism in public schools is unconstitutional.

## July

* July 1: The Single European Act comes into effect, which will lead to the creation of the European Union.
* July 11: The world's population is estimated to have reached 5 billion people.
* July 17: The Dow Jones Industrial Average closes above 2,500 for the first time.

## August

* August 1: The Federal Communications Commission (FCC) rescinds the fairness doctrine, which had required broadcasters to present balanced coverage of controversial issues.
* August 16: Northwest Airlines Flight 255 crashes on takeoff from Detroit Metropolitan Wayne County Airport, killing 156 people.
* August 19: The United Kingdom and Ireland sign the Anglo-Irish Agreement, which will lead to the establishment of a power-sharing government in Northern Ireland.

## September

* September 1: The Montreal Protocol is signed by over 150 countries, which will lead to the phasing out of ozone-depleting substances.
* September 7: The United States and the Soviet Union sign a treaty on the limitation of strategic arms.
* September 16: The Dow Jones Industrial Average closes above 2,600 for the first time.

## October

* October 1: The Whittier Narrows earthquake strikes the San Gabriel Valley in California, killing 8 people and causing widespread damage.
* October 19: The Black Monday stock market crash occurs, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling by 508 points, or 22.6%.
* October 26: The United States and the Soviet Union sign a treaty on the limitation of nuclear testing.

## November

* November 1: The United States and the Soviet Union agree to reduce their nuclear arsenals by 50%.
* November 18: The King's Cross fire occurs in London, killing 31 people and injuring over 100.
* November 29: Korean Air Lines Flight 858 is destroyed by a bomb, killing 115 people.

## December

* December 1: NASA's Space Shuttle Atlantis is launched on its maiden voyage.
* December 8: The Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty is signed by the United States and the Soviet Union.
* December 20: The MV Doña Paz collides with the MT Vector and sinks, killing over 4,000 people in the deadliest peacetime maritime disaster in history.

## Date unknown

* The first GPS satellite is launched by the United States.
* The first Hubble Space Telescope servicing mission is conducted by the Space Shuttle Discovery.

article:
Ponniyin Selvan: I

Ponniyin Selvan: I is a 2022 Indian Tamil-language historical drama film directed by Mani Ratnam, who co-wrote it with Elango Kumaravel and B. Jeyamohan. The film is the first installment of a two-part adaptation of Kalki Krishnamurthy's 1955 novel Ponniyin Selvan, which is based on the Chola dynasty. The film features a large ensemble cast, including Vikram, Aishwarya Rai Bachchan, Jayam Ravi, and Karthi.

#Plot

The film is set in the 10th century and revolves around the story of Arulmozhi Varman, a young prince of the Chola dynasty, who is destined to become the greatest emperor of the Chola Empire. The story begins with the introduction of Aditya Karikalan, the crown prince of the Chola Empire, who is on a mission to conquer the neighboring kingdoms. Meanwhile, Vandiyathevan, a brave and loyal warrior, is sent by the king to inform Aditya about the impending danger from the neighboring kingdoms.

As the story unfolds, we see the complex web of relationships between the characters, including the love story between Aditya and Nandini, the daughter of the rival king. We also see the struggles of the Chola Empire, which is facing a severe drought and is threatened by the neighboring kingdoms.

The film takes a dramatic turn when Aditya is killed in a battle, and the throne is passed on to his younger brother, Arulmozhi Varman. The film ends with Arulmozhi Varman being crowned as the new emperor, and the stage is set for the second part of the story.

#Cast

The film features a large ensemble cast, including:

* Vikram as Aditya Karikalan
* Aishwarya Rai Bachchan as Nandini
* Jayam Ravi as Arulmozhi Varman
* Karthi as Vandiyathevan
* Trisha as Kundavai
* Aishwarya Lekshmi as Poonguzhali
* Sobhita Dhulipala as Vaanathi
* Prabhu as Periya Pazhuvettaraiyar
* Sarathkumar as Pazhuvettaraiyar
* Vikram Prabhu as Parthibendra Pallavan
* Jayaram as Azhwarkadiyan Nambi
* Prakash Raj as Sundara Chola

#Production

The film was produced by Mani Ratnam's production company, Madras Talkies, and Lyca Productions. The film was shot in various locations across India, including Chennai, Hyderabad, and Mysore. The film's cinematography was handled by Ravi Varman, and the editing was done by A. Sreekar Prasad.

The film's budget was estimated to be around 500 crore rupees, making it one of the most expensive Tamil films ever made. The film's shooting began in December 2019 and was completed in September 2021.

#Music

The film's music was composed by A. R. Rahman, who also composed the background score. The film's soundtrack features six songs, including "Ponni Nadhi", "Chol Chol", and "Ratchasa Maamaney". The film's music was widely praised by critics and audiences alike.

#Marketing

The film's marketing campaign was handled by Lyca Productions and Madras Talkies. The film's trailer was released on July 8, 2022, and it received a massive response from fans and critics alike. The film's posters and teasers were also widely shared on social media platforms.

#Release

##Theatrical

The film was released in theaters on September 30, 2022. The film was released in Tamil, Telugu, Malayalam, Kannada, and Hindi languages. The film received a massive opening at the box office, with many theaters reporting full houses.

##Distribution

The film was distributed by Lyca Productions and Madras Talkies in India. The film was also distributed by various other companies in other countries, including the United States, the United Kingdom, and Australia.

##Home media

The film was released on various home media platforms, including Amazon Prime Video, on November 4, 2022.

#Reception

##Critical response

The film received widespread critical acclaim from critics. Many critics praised the film's direction, acting, music, and cinematography. The film holds a 92% approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes, with many critics praising the film's epic scope and grandeur.

##Box office

The film was a massive commercial success at the box office. The film grossed over 500 crore rupees in India and over 100 crore rupees in other countries. The film's worldwide gross was estimated to be over 600 crore rupees.

##Controversies

The film was involved in several controversies, including a plagiarism row and a controversy over the film's portrayal of certain historical figures.

#Accolades

The film won several awards, including the National Film Award for Best Feature Film in Tamil. The film also won several other awards, including the Filmfare Award for Best Film in Tamil and the SIIMA Award for Best Film in Tamil.

#Sequel

The film's sequel, Ponniyin Selvan: II, is currently in production and is expected to be released in 2024.

#Notes

* The film is based on the novel of the same name by Kalki Krishnamurthy.
* The film is the first installment of a two-part adaptation of the novel.
* The film's budget was estimated to be around 500 crore rupees.
* The film's music was composed by A. R. Rahman.
